panels.title: üìä Four Golden Signals - INT531 SRE Monitoring

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Latency is critical for user experience. High latency indicates performance issues that directly impact user satisfaction. This measures the end-to-end request latency from the frontend proxy to backend.

**What It Measures:**
P95 response time of requests proxied through Nginx to the backend. This represents the latency experienced by 95% of users.

**Note:** Standard nginx-exporter (stub_status) doesn't provide latency metrics, so we measure the backend response time which reflects the total latency from Nginx's perspective.
panels.title: üïê Latency (Frontend‚ÜíBackend P95)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Request rate indicates user traffic patterns and helps identify traffic spikes or drops. This is crucial for capacity planning and detecting anomalies in user behavior.

**What It Measures:**
Total HTTP requests per second handled by Nginx frontend proxy.
panels.title: üìà Traffic (Frontend Requests/sec)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Active connections show current load on the frontend. High active connections can indicate capacity issues or the need to scale. This helps predict when resources will be exhausted.

**What It Measures:**
Current number of active client connections to Nginx, including connections that are reading, writing, or waiting.
panels.title: ‚ö° Saturation (Active Connections)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Accepted vs handled connection ratio reveals if Nginx is dropping connections due to resource limits. Drops indicate saturation and potential user experience issues.

**What It Measures:**
Total number of accepted and handled connections. Difference between accepted and handled indicates dropped connections.
panels.title: ‚úÖ Connection Success Rate %

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This? (SRE Perspective)**

Waiting connections reveal important insights about your frontend's keep-alive configuration and connection management:

**1. Keep-Alive Efficiency:** Idle connections waiting for the next request indicate that HTTP keep-alive is working. This reduces latency by reusing connections.

**2. Connection Pool Health:** The ratio of waiting vs. active connections shows efficiency. Too many waiting connections may indicate:
   - Misconfigured keep-alive timeout (too long)
   - Connection leaks
   - Need to tune worker_connections limits

**3. Resource Planning:** Each idle connection consumes memory. Monitor trends to optimize keep-alive settings for balance between performance and resource usage.

**4. Anomaly Detection:** Sudden spikes in waiting connections may indicate slow clients, DDoS attempts, or application issues.

**What It Measures:**
- **Waiting Connections:** Idle keep-alive connections waiting for next request
- **Trend:** Sparkline shows changes over time
- **Efficiency:** Percentage shown indicates connection reuse rate

**Healthy Range:** 0-50 is normal; >100 may need investigation.
panels.title: ‚è≥ Keep-Alive Connections (Waiting)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Tracking latency percentiles over time helps identify performance degradation trends and the impact on different user segments. P50 shows typical experience, P95/P99 show worst-case scenarios.

**What It Measures:**
Frontend (Nginx) to Backend (Ktor) response time percentiles:
- P50: Median user experience
- P95: 95% of requests complete within this time
- P99: 99% of requests (catches outliers)

**Note:** Measures backend response time as seen from Nginx proxy.
panels.title: Frontend‚ÜíBackend Latency Percentiles

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Average response time provides a simple overall health indicator. Sudden increases indicate performance issues affecting all users.

**What It Measures:**
Average (mean) response time for requests proxied through Nginx to the backend. This is the total request processing time from Nginx's perspective.
panels.title: Frontend‚ÜíBackend Average Response Time

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Trends in request rate help identify patterns, predict capacity needs, and detect anomalies like DDoS attacks or traffic drops due to outages.

**What It Measures:**
HTTP request rate over time from Nginx.
panels.title: Frontend Request Rate Over Time

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Connection state distribution reveals bottlenecks. High 'reading' suggests slow clients, high 'writing' indicates slow responses or large payloads, high 'waiting' shows keep-alive usage.

**What It Measures:**
- Reading: Connections reading request headers
- Writing: Connections sending responses to clients
- Waiting: Idle keep-alive connections
panels.title: Connection States (Reading/Writing/Waiting)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Active connections trend indicates overall system load and helps with capacity planning. Sudden spikes may indicate attacks or viral traffic.

**What It Measures:**
Total active connections to Nginx frontend over time.
panels.title: Active Connections Over Time

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This?**
Comparing accepted vs handled connections reveals if Nginx is operating at capacity. Dropped connections (accepted - handled) indicate resource exhaustion requiring immediate attention.

**What It Measures:**
- Accepted: Total connections accepted by Nginx
- Handled: Total connections successfully handled
- Gap indicates dropped connections
panels.title: Accepted vs Handled Connections

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This? (SRE Perspective)**

Traffic is one of the Four Golden Signals and a critical SRE metric. Monitoring request rate helps:

**1. Capacity Planning:** Understand current load to predict when scaling is needed before saturation occurs.

**2. Anomaly Detection:** Sudden drops indicate outages or upstream failures; unexpected spikes may signal DDoS attacks or viral events.

**3. SLO/SLI Tracking:** Traffic volume is essential context for interpreting error rates and latency (errors/traffic = error rate).

**4. Business Metrics:** Request rate correlates with user activity and business health.

**What It Measures:**
Total number of HTTP requests per second handled by the backend API.
panels.title: üìà Traffic (Requests/sec)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This? (SRE Perspective)**

Errors are one of the Four Golden Signals and directly impact reliability and user trust. Monitoring error rates is critical for:

**1. SLO/SLI Measurement:** Error rate is typically the most important SLO (e.g., "99.9% of requests succeed"). Breaching error budgets triggers incident response.

**2. Rapid Incident Detection:** Spikes in 5xx errors indicate backend failures requiring immediate investigation.

**3. User Experience:** Every error affects users and may cause data loss, failed transactions, or poor perception.

**4. Change Validation:** Monitor error rates during deployments to catch regressions quickly.

**What It Measures:**
Percentage of requests returning 5xx server errors (failures caused by backend issues).
panels.title: ‚ùå Errors (5xx Error Rate %)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This? (SRE Perspective)**

Saturation is one of the Four Golden Signals and indicates how "full" your service is. CPU saturation monitoring is essential for:

**1. Preventing Cascading Failures:** High CPU usage causes increased latency, timeouts, and eventually service crashes. Early detection prevents outages.

**2. Capacity Planning:** Trend analysis shows when additional resources are needed before users are impacted.

**3. Cost Optimization:** Right-sizing infrastructure based on actual utilization prevents over-provisioning.

**4. Performance Baseline:** Abnormal CPU spikes indicate inefficient code, memory leaks, or unexpected workloads.

**What It Measures:**
CPU utilization percentage (100% - idle time) across all cores.
panels.title: ‚ö° Saturation (CPU Usage %)

panels.description:
**Why Monitor This? (SRE Perspective)**

Breaking down traffic by status code provides actionable insights for SRE work:

**1. Incident Triage:** Quickly distinguish between client errors (4xx - user/config issues) and server errors (5xx - backend failures) to focus response efforts.

**2. Deployment Validation:** Compare status code distribution before/after deployments to detect regressions.

**3. Capacity Analysis:** High 2xx volume with low latency indicates healthy capacity; high 2xx with high latency suggests approaching limits.

**4. Security Monitoring:** Unusual patterns in 4xx errors may indicate attacks (e.g., high 401/403 from authentication failures).

**What It Measures:**
Request rate over time broken down by HTTP status code categories (2xx success, 4xx client errors, 5xx server errors).
panels.title: Latency ‚Äì p95 by Route
